description.plain:
Hip-hop is often perceived as music’s boys club. However, as MC Lyte’s career would attest, the microphone is an equal opportunity employer. One of the best female MCs to rock the mic, Lana Michelle Moorer was raised in Brooklyn and began rapping at the age of 12.

When she was only 18, she released her classic album Lyte as a Rock. She held her own on each subsequent album, even becoming the the first solo female rapper to earn a Grammy Nomination with her song “Ruffneck”. As one of the most talented MCs during rap’s nascent years, MC Lyte’s longevity became evident over 3 decades in the music business. Savvy and multitalented, she has ventured into television, movies, and Broadway.

Amazingly, though, MC Lyte’s most meaningful work has come off-stage. Lyte has contributed to the Smithsonian Institute and lectured for universities and organizations throughout the world. However, she is proudest of her Hip Hop Sisters Foundation which awards yearly scholarships to young women who work hard inside the classroom and the booth.

A transcendent artist, MC Lyte is an OG and deserves credit for paving the way for MCs of any gender.

description.plain:
This remix of “Cold Rock A Party” became MC Lyte’s next chart-climbing single after the success of “Keep On, Keepin' On” from the soundtrack of the movie Sunset Park.

MC Lyte scored a #1 Billboard Rap Singles with this Diana Ross-sampling track by hitmaker Puff Daddy featuring a verse from a new rising star named Missy Elliott with her off-the-wall lyrics and trademark “hee-hee-haw.”

description.plain:
This song is about continuing to do what you’ve always done and never stopping.
This also Lyte’s highest charting single in the U.S. and also became her second single to achieve a gold certification from the RIAA, earning the award on May 31, 1996.
And this song also sampled MJ’s Liberian Girl.

songs.full_title: Ruffneck by MC Lyte
songs.title: Ruffneck

description.plain:
Long before Destiny’s Child attempted to get ‘street cred’ by claiming they needed a “Soldier,” or Rihanna was playfully challenging her “Rude Boy”, the original bad-ass MC Lyte spoke up for a lot of ladies who love thugs, bad boys & gangsters with “Ruffneck” – the first single from her fourth album Ain’t No Other.

The song was produced by Wreckx-n-Effect members Aqil Davidson and Markel Riley, who built track on a sample of James Brown’s “The Payback”. It was Lyte’s first top 40 single in the US and her fourth to hit #1 on the Rap Chart. It was also her first to be certified gold by the RIAA and gave her the honor of being the first female solo rapper to get a Grammy nomination.

songs.full_title: 10% Dis by MC Lyte
songs.title: 10% Dis

description.plain:
Here’s the timeline:


Antoinette recorded “I Got an Attitude”, which had a broadly similar beat to “Top Billin'” the breakout hit of the group Audio Two.
Audio Two didn’t want to diss a female MC, so they had their affiliate, MC Lyte, do it: this song was the result.
A full-fledged beef formed between Antoinette and Lyte, lasting a bunch of noticeable songs.



In Check the Technique, Lyte notes:

We went into INS [Studios] two days later and [made this track]. It was pretty easy—we just sat there and thought of the worst things we cuold possibly say about somebody [laughs]. It’s titled that because that’s only ten percent of what I could have said. I didn’t even know Antoinette. It was strictly a war on wax. She tried to dis me back but the hype on me was so big that no one cared if she had a rebuttal to it. I think she was from Queens. We actually had a battle once at the World. I won. Even then, it was understood completely that it was just business.

Antoinette recorded “I Got an Attitude”, which had a broadly similar beat to “Top Billin'” the breakout hit of the group Audio Two.
Audio Two didn’t want to diss a female MC, so they had their affiliate, MC Lyte, do it: this song was the result.
A full-fledged beef formed between Antoinette and Lyte, lasting a bunch of noticeable songs.



In Check the Technique, Lyte notes:

We went into INS [Studios] two days later and [made this track]. It was pretty easy—we just sat there and thought of the worst things we cuold possibly say about somebody [laughs]. It’s titled that because that’s only ten percent of what I could have said. I didn’t even know Antoinette. It was strictly a war on wax. She tried to dis me back but the hype on me was so big that no one cared if she had a rebuttal to it. I think she was from Queens. We actually had a battle once at the World. I won. Even then, it was understood completely that it was just business.

songs.title: I’m Not Havin’ It
songs.title_with_featured: I'm Not Havin' It (Ft. Positive K)

description.plain:
“I’m Not Havin' It” is the b-side to Positive K’s “A Good Combination”. It is a collab between Pos and MC Lyte where he’s trying to pick her up but she’s not impressed, and is the predecessor to his 1992 top 20 hit “I Got A Man” where Pos does a similar back and forth trying to pick up a girl who isn’t falling for him.

This song was Pos' first minor hit, reaching #16 on the US Rap Chart in the fall of 1989. It’s also Lyte’s first appearance on the US Rap Chart, but not because she didn’t have earlier hits – the chart was brand new that year.

songs.full_title: I Cram To Understand U by MC Lyte
songs.title: I Cram To Understand U

description.plain:
“I Cram To Understand U” was MC Lyte’s debut single. She wrote it when she was only 12 but it wasn’t pressed to vinyl until she was 16 years old.

In it, Lyte tells the story of meeting a man named Sam in 1981 who, while it seems he is cheating on her with another girl, it turns out he is actually addicted to crack cocaine. Her reason for writing “I Cram To Understand” was to warn people about the bad effects of drugs:

My mother used to work at North General Hospital in Harlem. Whenever I would go there would be a slew of heroin and crack addicts. I would never want that for myself or any other young person that I knew so I was going to make it my responsibility to tell people about drugs so that they could avoid them at all costs.

Medium.com reminisced about the song, noting:

She took a complex social issue that destroyed many black communities in the 80s and discussed it through the universal theme of love, thus humanizing addiction and giving listeners a new way of approaching the conversation.

See, back when Lyte released her legendary female diss track “10% Dis”, which if you don’t know was a diss aimed at then newcomer Antoinette, Antoinette then responded with “Lights Out, Party’s Over”.

Lyte silenced this beef once and for all with this track.



This track contains samples of “10% Dis” and “Cappucino”. The opening clip is from Millie Jackson’s “All The Way Lover”
